author: AOL Staff
title: Thousands of homes remain without power in wake of Storm Gerrit
text: Thousands of homes remain without power in wake of Storm Gerrit Thousands of homes remain without power as the post-storm cleanup begins in the wake of Storm Gerrit. Around 1,500 homes in Scotland experienced their second night without power in Scotland while a lightning strike hit supplies in Wales on Thursday. Power company Scottish and Southern Electricity Networks said it had restored supply to more than 46,000 properties that lost power due to the storm, with people in the north east and Shetland worst affected. ‚ö° We've now restored power to 46k customers [#stormgerrit]üè† 1.5k will be off overnight, we're giving help & advice.üë∑ Teams are working tonight to clear debris hindering access to faults.‚òï Full details of vans serving hot meals from 9am tomorrow are at [https://t.co/HSBcM400Fh] [pic.twitter.com/pnHIApyUvC] ‚Äî Scottish and Southern Electricity Networks (@ssencommunity) [December 28, 2023] They said the remaining homes should be reconnected on Friday with welfare vans serving hot food and drink to affected customers from 9am. Operations director Andy Smith said: ‚ÄúThis has been a difficult couple of days for the communities affected and I‚Äôm grateful to them for their patience and support as our teams work extremely hard to restore power.‚Äù National Grid UK said 36,000 properties were without power in Ceredigion on Thursday after lightning struck. Three men died after their 4√ó4 vehicle was submerged in the River Esk, near Glaisdale, on Thursday, North Yorkshire Police said. A supercell thunderstorm moved across the northwest of England on Thursday after a similar storm is thought to have resulted in a tornado that damaged homes in Greater Manchester on Wednesday. Around 100 properties were damaged by what police called a ‚Äúlocalised tornado‚Äù in Stalybridge, Tameside and in the badly-hit village of Carrbrook. Hayley McCaffer, 40, who lives in Carrbrook, told the PA news agency that some of her neighbours‚Äô houses ‚Äúare an absolute disaster‚Äù with missing roofs and ‚Äúsquished‚Äù cars. Damage will be covered by standard property insurance policies, the Association of British Insurers has said. ScotRail said many lines have been reopened but urged passengers to check for the latest information before travelling, a message echoed by LNER, Avanti West Coast and London Northwestern Railway who suspensed or cancelled services due to damage or system faults. Friday will see significant disruption for travellers wishing to travel on the London Euston and Watford Junction lines with services expected to be up and running by the end of the day. In Wales, the aftermath of the recent severe weather will see rail services hampered until Monday. üå¶Ô∏è Blustery showers are possible on Friday morning, with these most likely in the north and west. Many of us will also see some sunshine and some places may stay dry. üå¨Ô∏è Still windy in northern England and later Shetland, with gales possible, but otherwise somewhat less windy. [pic.twitter.com/hInP8LNF2c] ‚Äî Met Office (@metoffice) [December 28, 2023] Ferry services also experienced cancellations and delays due to storm activity with operator DFDS confirming sailings between Dover and France were delayed due to strong winds in the English Channel. Air travel in and out of the UK saw cancellations but most services have returned to normal. The Met Office reported the worst of Storm Gerrit had passed with the last few days of 2023 forecast to be unsettled with strong winds, rain and even snow on higher ground. Met Office chief forecaster Steven Ramsdale said: ‚ÄúHeavy rain will spread across all but the far north on Saturday, affecting similar areas previously affected by Storm Gerrit. However, this rainfall will be a step down from that seen during Storm Gerrit.‚Äù

Ê±ΩËΩ¶ÂèëÂ∏ÉÔºåÂäüÁéáÊ®°ÊãüÊúâÊúõÂ∫ïÈÉ®Â§çËãèËøõÂÖ•Â¢ûÈïøÈÄöÈÅì„ÄÇËÆæÂ§áÊùêÊñôÊñπÈù¢ÔºåSEMICONÊñ∞ÂìÅÂèëÂ∏ÉÂÇ¨ÂåñÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÊùêÊñôÂÖ¨Âè∏ÂíåËÆæÂ§áÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑ‰∏öÁª©Âú®Êñ∞‰∏ÄËΩÆÂπ∂Ë¥≠ÈáçÁªÑÁöÑÊé®Âä®‰∏ãÊòæÁ§∫Âá∫Â¢ûÈïøÊΩúÂäõÔºåÁé∞Èò∂ÊÆµÈÄöËøáËµÑÊú¨Ëøê‰ΩúÂÆûÁé∞ËµÑÊ∫ê‰ºòÂåñÈÖçÁΩÆÂèØËÉΩÊàê‰∏∫‰∏ÄÁßçË∂ãÂäø„ÄÇËøôÁßç‰∫ß‰∏öÊï¥ÂêàÊó¢ÊúâÂà©‰∫éÂ§¥ÈÉ®‰ºÅ‰∏öÊâìÈÄ†ÁªºÂêàÂûãÊäÄÊúØÂπ≥Âè∞ÔºåÊèêÂçá‰∏éÂõΩÈôÖÁ´û‰∫âÂØπÊâãÁöÑÂØπÊäóËÉΩÂäõÔºåÂèàËÉΩÈÄöËøá‰∏ä‰∏ãÊ∏∏ÂçèÂêåÂèëÂ±ïÂÆåÂñÑÊú¨Âúü‰∫ß‰∏öÈìæÈÖçÂ•óÔºåÊé®Âä®ÂõΩ‰∫ßËÆæÂ§áÂú®Â§öÂ∑•Ëâ∫ÁéØËäÇÂÆûÁé∞Êõø‰ª£Á™ÅÁ†¥„ÄÇÂÜõÂ∑•ÁîµÂ≠êÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÂ∫ïÈÉ®ÂèçËΩ¨Ë∂ãÂäøÂ∑≤Áé∞ÔºåÊåÅÁª≠Âª∫ËÆÆÈáçÁÇπÂÖ≥Ê≥®„ÄÇÂΩìÂâç‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂçÅÂõõ‰∫îËßÑÂàíÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄÂπ¥ÔºåÊúâÊúõÈáäÊîæ‰πãÂâçÂª∂ËøüÁöÑËÆ¢ÂçïÔºåÂè†Âä†‚ÄúÂçÅ‰∫î‰∫î‚ÄùËßÑÂàíÂàùÊúüÊñ∞Ë£ÖÂ§áÂ∏¶Êù•Êñ∞‰∏ÄËΩÆÂ§áË¥ßÂë®ÊúüÔºåÂêåÊó∂‰º¥ÈöèÊàëÂÜõ‰ø°ÊÅØÂåñËøõÁ®ãËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Âä†Ê∑±ÔºåËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Ë°•ÈΩêÁîµÂ≠êÂØπÊäó„ÄÅÂÜõÂ∑•Êï∞ÊçÆÈìæÁ≠âÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊäÄÊúØÈ¢ÜÂüüÁü≠ÊùøÔºåÂÜõÂ∑•‰ø°ÊÅØÂåñÊùøÂùóÊúâÊúõËøéÊù•Êï¥‰ΩìË°å‰∏öËÆ¢ÂçïÊÅ¢Â§çÂ∏¶Êù•Âü∫Êú¨Èù¢ÂèçËΩ¨Êú∫‰ºö„ÄÇAISoCÊñπÈù¢Ôºå3Êúà27Êó•ÔºåÂú®ÊàêÈÉΩ‰∏æÂäûÁöÑÁ¨¨ÂçÅ‰∫åÂ±ä‰∏≠ÂõΩÁΩëÁªúËßÜÂê¨Â§ß‰ºöÊô∫ÊÖßÂ™í‰ΩìËÆ∫Âùõ‰∏äÔºå ‰∫∫Ê∞ëÁΩë ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜÊô∫ËÉΩÁ°¨‰ª∂‚ÄúAI‰πãÁúº‚Äù„ÄÇËøôÊ¨æËÆæÂ§áÁöÑ1.0ÁâàÊú¨Âêç‰∏∫‚ÄúAlyou(Áà±Ê∏∏)‚ÄùÔºåÊòØ‰∫∫Ê∞ëÁΩëÁ†îÂèëÁöÑÈ¶ñÊ¨æÊô∫ËÉΩÁ°¨‰ª∂„ÄÇ4ÊúàÊù•ÁúãÔºå4Êúà2Êó•ÁÅ´Â±±ÂºïÊìéAIoTÊô∫ÂèòÊµ™ÊΩÆ‰ºöÔºå4Êúà23Êó•MetaÁúºÈïúÂèëÂ∏ÉËØ¥Êòé„ÄÇ

author: Ambitocom
title: Los Juegos Ol√≠mpicos ya son historia, pero la pol√©mica con el boxeo no termina
text:
El boxeo ol√≠mpico contin√∫a en el centro de la pol√©mica tras las acusaciones de corrupci√≥n contra la Asociaci√≥n Internacional de Boxeo (IBA) y la exclusi√≥n de dos jueces kazajos durante los Juegos Ol√≠mpicos de Par√≠s 2024 , que reavivaron el debate sobre la integridad del arbitraje en el deporte.
El contenido al que quiere acceder es exclusivo para suscriptores.
suscribirse ya estoy suscripto
Informate m√°s La pol√©mica no afect√≥ a Imane Khelif, que es finalista y se garantiz√≥ una medalla en Par√≠s 2024 La boxeadora argelina Imane khelif rompi√≥ el silencio y respondi√≥ a las cr√≠ticas Los jueces Alisher Altayev, con un nivel de alto riesgo y Yermek Suiyenish con nivel de riesgo medio, fueron removidos a mitad del torneo por posibles delitos de corrupci√≥n.
La exclusi√≥n de ambos jueces, que participaron en un total de 46 combates, fue una se√±al de preocupaci√≥n sobre la transparencia en el arbitraje, especialmente en una disciplina que ha enfrentado irregularidades en las ediciones pasadas de los Juegos Ol√≠mpicos .
Las cr√≠ticas no se limitaron a la remoci√≥n de los jueces, ya que en Italia la boxeadora Irma Testa critic√≥ el nivel del arbitraje tras su eliminaci√≥n en primera ronda.
Embed - https://publish.twitter.com/oembed?url=https://x.com/EstrellaOnline/status/1824173572178448719&partner=&hide_thread=false La medallista ol√≠mpica, Atheyna Bylon habl√≥ sobre la posibilidad de que no pueda haber boxeo en los Juegos Ol√≠mpicos Los √Ångeles 2028 y afirm√≥ que ‚Äútiene fe‚Äù de que dir√° presente en la siguiente justa ol√≠mpica.
: @jpfrancis18 pic.twitter.com/ib7fd0lv5j
‚Äî La Estrella | Panam√° (@EstrellaOnline) August 15, 2024 El Comit√© Ol√≠mpico Internacional (COI) se ha mostrado cada vez m√°s reticente a supervisar el boxeo en futuras ediciones de los Juegos, llegando a advertir que el deporte podr√≠a ser eliminado del programa de Los Angeles 2028 si no se encuentra una federaci√≥n fiable.
Ante este panorama, World Boxing , una nueva organizaci√≥n impulsada por Gran Breta√±a y Estados Unidos, ha emergido como la √∫nica alternativa viable para garantizar la continuidad del boxeo ol√≠mpico.
Con el apoyo creciente de federaciones nacionales, World Boxing busca reemplazar a la IBA y asegurar que el boxeo siga siendo parte de los Juegos Ol√≠mpicos en los pr√≥ximos a√±os.
En tanto, durante Par√≠s 2024 la pol√©mica en el boxeo estall√≥ desde el inicio. Las peleadoras Imane Khelif y Lin Yu-ting, ambas ganadoras de la medalla de oro en sus respectivas categor√≠as, fueron fuertemente cuestionadas por su g√©nero ya que muchos adujeron que sus gen√©ticas eran masculinas.

author: T Venkateshwara Swamy
title: Pedda Hanuman Jayanti celebrated grandly
text: Karimnagar : Pedda Hanuman Jayanthi, which is held every year on Vaisakh Bahula Dashami, was celebrated with grandeur at Sri Anjaneya Swamy Devasthanam in Kondagattu on Saturday.The temple priests recited Thirumanjanam at 3 am and decorated the presiding deity with sandalwood. Water was brought from Pushkarini with bindas and abhishekam, panchamrita ksharabhishekam, and sahasranagavalli archana was performed to the deity that was decorated with silk cloths and beautiful flowers. In the yagashala, Vedic scholars and priests performed the Yajna ritual and decorated the Swami‚Äôs ceremonial idol with silk clothes.Later, they performed ‚ÄòOoyala‚Äô seva. The Utsava idols were brought to the temple from the Yagasala, Mantra Pushpam and Mahanivedana were offered and theertha prasadam was given to the devotees. Aradhana performed in evening.More than two lakh initiates and devotees reached Kondagattu on foot from all corners of the state to celebrate Hanuman‚Äôs Pedda Jayanthi.As a large number of initiates and devotees flocked to the celebrations in various vehicles, the cellars set up by the temple authorities for the initiation ceremony in front of the viramana mandap were filled. Along with cellars, devotees also queued in queue lines. Similarly, the three vehicle parking spaces set up from JNTU to Bojja Pothana and the vehicle parking space under Gutta were completely filled with devotees‚Äô vehicles till Friday night.

author: Gordon Sargent
title: ‚ÄòI earned my PGA Tour card in college‚Äô: Gordon Sargent is ready to win like buddy Nick Dunlap | Golf News and Tour Information | Golf Digest
text:
W hen the PGA Tour announced the PGA Tour U Accelerated program in which a college player can earn his tour card by winning enough amateur tournaments and awards before his senior year, I knew I had a chance. No one is more excited about the program than I am: I‚Äôm a junior, playing college golf at Vanderbilt, but I already have my PGA Tour card. After the NCAA Championship, I can turn pro and start playing on tour.
I grew up going to the course with my dad . I‚Äôve always been around the game but never forced into it. The drive to get better came from me, and that gave me ownership over my game. We‚Äôre members at The Country Club of Birmingham, and all summer my brother, our friends and I would get dropped off in the morning and picked up in the evening. Chipping contests would turn into wiffle ball games. The goal was to have fun.
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
I was 9 when I played the Future Masters in Dothan, Ala., where there were lots of people and everything was official. I didn‚Äôt play great that first year, but the next year I played a lot better. I vividly remember seeing the growth in my game. That‚Äôs what got me addicted to golf. I played team sports‚Äîbaseball and basketball‚Äîbut I loved that with golf I could see the progress clearly through my scores.
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
My friends and I saw older kids at our club play college golf, and we realized that we could do that, too. We worked harder. I stopped playing baseball and basketball in sixth grade to focus on golf. Honestly, I wish I had stuck with other sports longer. Those sports gave me a basic level of athleticism that I didn‚Äôt get from playing golf. I brought my strength and coordination from playing other sports to golf, which gave me a big advantage.
Ross Parker/R&A
I was always pretty small, so I learned how to swing hard to get as much distance as possible. I never did speed training, but swinging hard as a little kid taught me how to rotate and use the ground. During my junior year of high school, I grew a few inches and started hitting it much farther, so I worked on control. I strengthened my core, which made me stable enough to handle fast swing speeds. The coaches at Vanderbilt had been recruiting me but didn‚Äôt see me for a year because of COVID. When they saw me again, during my senior year, I had become a bomber.
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
I knew Vanderbilt was the right spot for me. Vandy is a three-hour drive from Birmingham‚Äîjust far enough so that I wouldn‚Äôt have my parents knocking on my door every day. A guy I knew from Birmingham, Patrick Martin, played golf at Vanderbilt. He told me to learn how to do things on my own before college, like doing your own laundry and managing your own schedule. The less I had to figure out at college, the more headspace I would have for golf.
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
We worked on course management as a team‚Äîthat‚Äôs the biggest difference between junior and college golf: To be successful in college, you must learn where to hit it off the tee, when par is a good score and which pins to avoid hunting. The 2022 NCAA Championship was at Grayhawk Golf Club in Arizona, and after 72 holes, I was tied at the top with three other guys. The first playoff hole was 18. It‚Äôs a driver hole.
I knew somebody had to step up and take it. I was nervous, but I hit my driver exactly where I wanted to. I had 140 yards in on the 520-yard hole. You can do the math. I wouldn‚Äôt have gone for the tricky pin in regulation, but I had a good number so I decided to be aggressive. When the five-footer to win fell, I didn‚Äôt process it for a few days. When I watched the video of the final putt, and I saw how happy my teammates and family were, the moment felt real.
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
About six months later, I got a call from Augusta National Golf Club. I could not believe the invitation to the Masters was real. An amateur hadn‚Äôt received a special invitation since 2000. It hurt to miss the cut, but playing the Masters and the 2023 U.S. Open allowed me to test my game against the best pros. I can hit it a long way, but distance is not as much of an advantage in the pro game. In college, you can get away with missing in the wrong spots. You can‚Äôt do that in professional golf. Playing alongside those guys, I saw that you want your rounds to look boring and methodical.
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
By creating the Accelerated program, the tour is letting us college guys know they want us out there. We were all cheering for Nick Dunlap when he won in Palm Springs. I‚Äôve played against him and was his teammate in the Walker Cup. Seeing a guy that I‚Äôve beaten win on tour gives me confidence and motivation to know that my first tour win is not that far away.
More from Golf Digest cover story How To Compete: Nick Dunlap's keys to playing your best when it matters
‚óè ‚óè ‚óè
The program allows me to defer turning pro. I‚Äôve decided to stay at Vanderbilt through my senior year. Education has always been important in our family, so I want to get my degree. By staying, I get another year to develop as a player with coach Limbaugh and my teammates. I signed NIL deals with Nike and Titleist, and they both supported my decision. So, I'm staying, and we‚Äôre getting to work to win a team NCAA Championship. -- with Keely Levins
RELATED: The science behind golf's newest bomber

author: Tyler Allender
title: Strong to severe storms end Friday morning
text: By Tyler Allender,3 hours ago By Tyler Allender,3 hours ago Read in NewsBreak [Ashland, VA](/ashland-va)11 hours ago [Newport News, VA](/newport-news-va)29 days ago [Tupelo, MS](/tupelo-ms)1 day ago [Kansas City, MO](/kansas-city-mo)28 days ago [Orlando, FL](/orlando-fl)17 days ago Coroner‚Äôs office identifies individual who died at Sunday‚Äôs commencement ceremony, says incident is being investigated as death by suicide [Columbus, OH](/columbus-oh)1 day ago [Fort Myers, FL](/fort-myers-fl)27 days ago [Key West, FL](/key-west-fl)14 days ago Welcome to NewsBreak, an open platform where diverse perspectives converge. Most of our content comes from established publications and journalists, as well as from our extensive network of tens of thousands of creators who contribute to our platform. We empower individuals to share insightful viewpoints through short posts and comments. It‚Äôs essential to note our commitment to transparency: our Terms of Use acknowledge that our services may not always be error-free, and our Community Standards emphasize our discretion in enforcing policies. We strive to foster a dynamic environment for free expression and robust discourse through safety guardrails of human and AI moderation. Join us in shaping the news narrative together.
